chapter.title: How to Learn Perl
chapter.para: In order to effectively use this reference, you need to be familiar with some common Perl basics and pitfalls. Teaching Perl is out of the scope of this document, but nonetheless, in this section we will refer you to common ways in which you can learn Perl.

One note is in order: Perl is positively huge and most tutorials and books cover only a subset of it to get going. As a result, you may find yourself suffering from the "for someone who only has a hammer, everything looks like a nail" syndrome. That is, you will try to achieve everythings using only the elements you've learned, and will still not have the tools to write professional Perl programs, much less read the code of experts.

section.title: Installing Perl
section.para: To get started using Perl, you should install it on your machine, so you can play with it. The first chapter of Simon Cozens' book Beginning Perl covers the basics of installing Perl on the most common systems.

section.title: Learning Perl
section.para: There are chiefly two ways to learn how to program Perl: from online resources or by reading a book.

There are several online resources that give a list of tutorials to learn Perl from. One of them is the Perl Beginners' Site Online Tutorials Section. Another, which is more encompassing, but less organized and descriptive is the relevant category from the Open Directory Project.

The online version of Simon Cozens' Beginning Perl book is probably the most comprehensive tutorial available. If you wish to get started even more quickly then you can try (at your own risk) a different tutorial listed in the resources above.

If you wish to purchase or borrow a book that will guide you through the first steps in Perl, then the Beginner Books category of the Perl Books site should be of help. It contains ratings, reviews, information and links about the commonly available books.

section.title: Resources in Foreign Languages
section.para: The French Perl Mongers (Perl mongers are Perl user groups around the globe) wrote an introduction to Perl in French. Semeul Vomberg wrote a Hebrew Tutorial for Perl.
